information.label: Critical Success
information.description: You understand the true meaning of the text.

information.label: Success
information.description: You understand the true meaning of the text. If it was a coded document, you know the general meaning but might not have a word-for-word translation.

information.label: Failure
information.description: You can’t understand the text and take a –2 circumstance penalty to further checks to decipher it.

information.label: Critical Failure
information.description: You believe you understand the text on that page, but you have in fact misconstrued its message.

examples.label: Expert
examples.description: complex code, such as a cipher

examples.label: Master
examples.description: spymaster’s code or advanced research notes

examples.label: Legendary
examples.description: esoteric planar text written in metaphor by an ancient celestial

information.label: Source
information.description: Core Rulebook pg. 238

information.label: Description
information.description: Once you discover that an item, location, or ongoing effect is magical, you can spend 10 minutes to try to identify the particulars of its magic. If your attempt is interrupted, you must start over. The GM sets the DC for your check. Cursed or esoteric subjects usually have higher DCs or might even be impossible to identify using this activity alone. Heightening a spell doesn’t increase the DC to identify it.

information.label: Critical Success
information.description: You learn all the attributes of the magic, including its name (for an effect), what it does, any means of activating it (for an item or location), and whether it is cursed.

information.label: Success
information.description: For an item or location, you get a sense of what it does and learn any means of activating it. For an ongoing effect (such as a spell with a duration), you learn the effect’s name and what it does. You can’t try again in hopes of getting a critical success.

information.label: Failure
information.description: You fail to identify the magic and can’t try again for 1 day.

information.label: Critical Failure
information.description: You misidentify the magic as something else of the GM’s choice.

information.label: Source
information.description: Core Rulebook pg. 238

information.label: Description
information.description: You can gain access to a new spell of your tradition from someone who knows that spell or from magical writing like a spellbook or scroll. If you can cast spells of multiple traditions, you can Learn a Spell of any of those traditions, but you must use the corresponding skill to do so. For example, if you were a cleric with the bard multiclass archetype, you couldn’t use Religion to add an occult spell to your bardic spell repertoire.  To learn the spell, you must do the following: Spend 1 hour per level of the spell, during which you must remain in conversation with a person who knows the spell or have the magical writing in your possession.  Have materials with the Price indicated in Table 4–3.  Attempt a skill check for the skill corresponding to your tradition (DC determined by the GM, often close to the DC on Table 4–3). Uncommon or rare spells have higher DCs; full guidelines for the GM appear on page 503.  If you have a spellbook, Learning a Spell lets you add the spell to your spellbook; if you prepare spells from a list, it’s added to your list; if you have a spell repertoire, you can select it when you add or swap spells.

information.label: Critical Success
information.description: You expend half the materials and learn the spell.

information.label: Success
information.description: You expend the materials and learn the spell.

information.label: Failure
information.description: You fail to learn the spell but can try again after you gain a level. The materials aren’t expended.

information.label: Critical Failure
information.description: As failure, plus you expend half the materials.

information.label: Source
information.description: Core Rulebook pg. 239

information.label: Description
information.description: To remember useful information on a topic, you can attempt to Recall Knowledge. You might know basic information about something without needing to attempt a check, but Recall Knowledge requires you to stop and think for a moment so you can recollect more specific facts and apply them. You might even need to spend time investigating first. For instance, to use Medicine to learn the cause of death, you might need to conduct a forensic examination before attempting to Recall Knowledge.  The following skills can be used to Recall Knowledge, getting information about the listed topics. In some cases, you can get the GM’s permission to use a different but related skill, usually against a higher DC than normal. Some topics might appear on multiple lists, but the skills could give different information. For example, Arcana might tell you about the magical defenses of a golem, whereas Crafting could tell you about its sturdy resistance to physical attacks.

information.label: Arcana
information.description: Arcane theories, magical traditions, creatures of arcane significance, and arcane planes.

information.label: Crafting
information.description: Alchemical reactions and creatures, item value, engineering, unusual materials, and constructs.

information.label: Lore
information.description: The subject of the Lore skill’s subcategory.

information.label: Medicine
information.description: Diseases, poisons, wounds, and forensics.

information.label: Nature
information.description: The environment, flora, geography, weather, creatures of natural origin, and natural planes.

information.label: Occultism
information.description: Ancient mysteries, obscure philosophy, creatures of occult significance, and esoteric planes.

information.label: Religion
information.description: Divine agents, divine planes, theology, obscure myths, and creatures of religious significance.

information.label: Society
information.description: Local history, key personalities, legal institutions, societal structure, and humanoid culture.

information.label: Critical Success
information.description: You recall the knowledge accurately and gain additional information or context.

information.label: Success
information.description: You recall the knowledge accurately or gain a useful clue about your current situation.

information.label: Failure
information.description: You don't recall the knowledge and cannot try again for 10 minutes.

information.label: Critical Failure
information.description: You recall incorrect information or gain an erroneous or misleading clue.

examples.label: Untrained
examples.description: name of a ruler, key noble, or major deity

examples.label: Trained
examples.description: line of succession for a major noble family, core doctrines of a major deity

examples.label: Expert
examples.description: genealogy of a minor noble, teachings of an ancient priest

examples.label: Master
examples.description: hierarchy of a genie noble court, major extraplanar temples of a deity

examples.label: Legendary
examples.description: existence of a long-lost noble heir, secret doctrines of a religion

information.label: Source
information.description: Core Rulebook pg. 240

information.label: Description
information.description: You try to provide food and shelter for yourself, and possibly others as well, with a standard of living described on page 294. The GM determines the DC based on the nature of the place where you’re trying to Subsist. You might need a minimum proficiency rank to Subsist in particularly strange environments. Unlike most downtime activities, you can Subsist after 8 hours or less of exploration, but if you do, you take a –5 penalty.

information.label: Critical Success
information.description: You either provide a subsistence living for yourself and one additional creature, or you improve your own food and shelter, granting yourself a comfortable living.

information.label: Success
information.description: You find enough food and shelter with basic protection from the elements to provide you a subsistence living.

information.label: Failure
information.description: You’re exposed to the elements and don’t get enough food, becoming fatigued until you attain sufficient food and shelter.

information.label: Critical Failure
information.description: You attract trouble, eat something you shouldn’t, or otherwise worsen your situation. You take a –2 circumstance penalty to checks to Subsist for 1 week. You don’t find any food at all; if you don’t have any stored up, you’re in danger of starving or dying of thirst if you continue failing.

examples.label: Untrained
examples.description: lush forest with calm weather or large city with plentiful resources

examples.label: Master
examples.description: typical desert or city under siege

examples.label: Legendary
examples.description: barren wasteland or city of undead
